title: At the end of a book, what are 'Acknowledgements'? - Quora

response.answer_text: "At the end of a book, what are "Acknowledgements"?"  It seems to me Acknowledgements are usually at the front of the book, but that's a detail. The point is to do exactly what the section title says: to acknowledge the contributions of people who helped you in some way.  I doubt most of the people who help would really care all that much about being mentioned in the acknowledgements, but it's a nice gesture. In my opinion, one of the most valuable things about acknowledging people who've helped is that it lets readers know the book wasn't just crafted in isolation.

An acknowledgment section at the end of the book (in the "postlims") is known in the publishing and printing trade as "Chinese acknowledgments." This isn't quite usual even in Chinese books, but when it does occur, it's located at the back. In Western books, acknowledgments are in the front (the "prelims"). Normally, there are no 'sections' to separate different kinds of contributors -- although there's no rule against having sections. Thanks for the A2A.

Here is a good explanation, and good examples, of Acknowledgements pages in a book. Basically, you get to thank the people involved with your book. How to Write an Acknowledgement Page | Greenleaf Book Group The 25 Best Author Acknowledgements Ever Written
